results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows family holidays and recreational activities including trips to the beach, road trips to regional Victoria, children’s playgrounds (including swings and slippery slides) farm animals, pets and women’s tennis.

There is footage of Melbourne during the 1956 Olympics, showing athletes warming up, relay track events, Flinders Street and St Paul’s Cathedral with Olympic decorations.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:00:01:00 VH INB aircraft flying overhead
00:00:07:00 children and adults on swings and see-saw in playground. Great vintage sunglasses.
00:00:27:00 close-ups of children’s faces at the beach
00:00:34:00 men in 1940s bathing suits (bathers, swimwear)
00:00:45:00 children and adults standing by road signs to Healesville, Narbethong, Donna Buang, Warburton
00:00:57:00 bird’s eye view of 1940s cars on country dirt road
00:01:13:00 stationary 1940s car on dirt road, with passenger looking out window and driver posing in front of the car
00:01:18:00 wooden fire tower
00:02:09:00 children and mother walking down stone steps of picnic ground. Good fashion shots.
00:02:16:00 parked 1940s car
00:02:45:00 country look-out point with telescope and vintage car
00:02:56:00 two children posing for camera (good vintage fashion shots)
00:03:05:00 hobby farm with children and adults patting goats and cows
00:03:51:00 children in birthday party clothes
00:04:09:00 children on slippery slide
00:05:00:00 group of children posing and waving to camera (good children’s fashion shots)
00:06:07:00 farm animals and pets
00:06:42:00 1950s parked cars
00:07:40:00 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games Village showing flags and Olympic rings sign
00:07:54:00 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games athletics track and field event, relay event, including athletes from the Philippines and USA
00:08:12:00 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games street scene with Olympic rings, trams and cars on Flinders Street easterly direction
00:08:21:00 St Paul’s Cathedral with Olympic Games street decorations
00: 08:27:00 1950s Coles shopfront with John Batman quote
00:08:32:00 family members: grandfather and two children (good fashion examples)
00:08:52:00 family pet shots. Patting wire-haired fox terrier, cockatoo.
00:09:19:00 c1940/1950 Women’s doubles tennis match

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is a composite film of different segments – a family reunion at Halls Gap in 1973 where we see typical barbeques of the era – a small round three legged hotplate and a ‘trough’ style both stacked with 1970’s barbeque fare – lots of lamb chops. We also see the fashions of the 1970’s in the velvets, flares, knee high socks and long hair. ‘Sandown Park with Jack Brabham’ introduces a segment of vintage racing cars and favourite car driver of the day, Jack Brabham signing autographs and smiling at the camera.

The film also includes some Moomba parade floats and marching girls, some city scenes of Melbourne and the Yarra Heliport and Ansett-ANA helicopter and finishes with some up close footage on the set of ‘World of Sport’, a very popular television sports show of the era featuring Lou Richards, Jack Dyer and Ron Casey among others.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection]
results.material_description:
5 x 400ft 9.5mm B&W silent home movies
7 x 8mm reels (4 x 100ft, 2 x 400ft)
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

Charles Edward Hayes was born on 28th March 1914 and grew up in Port Melbourne. In 1928 he joined Johns & Waygood in City Road, South Melbourne where he worked his way up from office boy to the machine shop becoming a fitter. In 1942 he was nominated to take charge of Johns & Waygood Munitions Annex in Montague making 10lb mortar bombs.

In the late 1940s, Charles purchased his first 9.5mm movie camera starting a hobby that would bring years of enjoyment. In November 1949 Charles purchased an Austin A40 car which he kept until 1973 – it also makes an appearance or two in the home movies! On the 11th November 1950, the family purchased a property at Miller Road, Heathmont, comprising 5 acres of land. They decided to build some sheds and try at being poultry farmers. Charles continued travelling to South Melbourne to work until 1956 when they became full time farmers.

Over the years the family had numerous cows, duck, pigs, sheep, dogs, cats and of course Ticka the cockatoo; all these animals were treated as pets. For socialising and fitness Charles with his wife Elsie, joined the local tennis club and enjoyed playing at the weekend. In 1958 Charles joined the Ringwood Movie Club through some friends and enjoyed the friendship of the club and continued to record their travels with his trusty home movie camera. In 1966 Charles went on to work for Nutritional Products in Mitcham, so they eased out of the poultry business.

Their daughter Olwyn married John Baker on the 9th July, 1967 and had two sons. Elenor married Ron Peach on 2nd April 1970 and had two daughters – Elenor kindly donated the films to ACMI. Elise and Charles were happily married more than 50 years, until he passed away in 1993. These films remain testament to a happy and hard-working family from Melbourne’s outer eastern suburbs.

This home movie collection was donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter, Elenor Peach.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows rural Victoria footage around Omeo. It features excavation of, and images of, the Kiewa Hydro Electric scheme including power station interiors and exteriors and dam footage. Also included are hobby farm images, of children and adults with calves and chickens and pet dogs and cats. There is footage of a man collecting cow manure from paddocks.

We see images of the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade with goats, horses, Ayrshire and Illawarra cattle, jinkers, floats, horse-drawn carts with advertising. There is also footage of children playing childhood games on the family farm – wheelbarrow races, chasey, ball games and piggy-backs.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan):

00:00:01:00 children feeding chickens on farm
00:00:11:00 child sitting on cow and falling off as cow stands
00:00:30:00 family and friends with farm animals
00:00:48:00 man working on farm with shovel collecting cow manure
00:00:59:00 two children with kitten fighting over who gets to hold it
00:01:15:00 children playing chasing, running games around trees in rural setting
00:01:26:00 children with grandmother playing with skipping rope in rural setting (good family images and fashion example)
00:01:35:00 family on ship with crew working in background
00:02:11:00 Maroondah Dam plaque with reservoir details
00:02:46:00 men and children playing piggy back, wheelbarrow races, ball games on rural property (ood footage of childhood games and playing)
00:03:15:00 child and woman on farm with calves (good rural footage and fashion example)
00:05:11:00 Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade including Ayrshire and Illawara cattle and goats
00:05:17:00 Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade with Jinkers, horses and carts, floats and advertising carts
00:08:19:00 Carnation Milk factory interior and exterior
00:08:57:00 Mount Beauty postal address plaque
00:10:01:00 rural footage of Kiewa Hydroelectric scheme, including images of interior and exterior power station, electricity poles and dam
00:10:33:00 road sign with vintage car in background: road sign indicating Upper Kiewa Valley Road; Mt Beauty; Rocky Valley; Howmans Gap

results.title: The Moving Record
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Robert Rothols
results.brief_description: A look at how film has been used to portray agriculture in Australia and particularly in Victoria between 1913 and 1985, and how film makers strengthened certain myths about city and country life. This compilation of old film footage was put together for the 150th anniversary of Victoria. Narrated by Sir Eric Pearce.

results.title: Russia crossing the Ukrainian border
results.brief_description: Russian President Vladimir Putin has ordered troops into the two Russian-controlled areas of Ukraine on “peacekeeping duties”. Western European leaders and the US continue to attempt to negotiate a peaceful outcome for Ukraine, but the presence of 190,000 Russian troops at the border is keeping the tension at boiling point. Is the Russian leader engaging in high-stakes political theatrics to prove a point to Nato, or is he going to take Ukraine and possibly other former USSR nations back under Russian control by force?

results.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
results.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

constellations_primary.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_primary.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.
description_for_label: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-09. Spotlights

results.title: Gaps
results.brief_description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. ‘Gaps’ embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship - or ‘gaps’ - between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on ‘Gaps’ include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed ‘How to Feel’ 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period. Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

details.label: Measurements
display_values:
Duration: 35 mins, 7 seconds
The work does not need to be seen from beginning to end, viewers are invited to approach and engage with the work at any point throughout the duration.

production_dates.notes:
Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney).
David Rosetzky: Gaps will be a free exhibition at ACMI from 5 August 2014 to 8 February 2015.
The co-commission of Gaps by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts, its arts funding and advisory body.

results.title: Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion [exhibition] : archival material
results.brief_description:
“Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion” was an ACMI Screen Gallery Exhibition, held 26 October 2002 - 27 January 2003.
See Exhibition activity record “Deep Space” (ID 3) for more information
The international and Australian contemporary artists in this exibition present environments, or chambers, for the visitor to participate in an all encompassing aesthetic experience. The audience is invited to move within the art works, to explore their physical construction, their digital presence, their filmic pulse and their saturated expanses of colour and light. The experiences vary: some are quiet, some intangible, others humourous or uncanny. Each involves an ephemeral medium, whether it be light, video or digital imagery and each encloses the viewer in a confined space only to offer them access to another expanded sense of space altogether. This exhibition offers visitors a memorable and transformative experience of being immersed in ‘deep space’, the kineasthetic, visual, aural and informational totality of the art works.
